questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman with a history of chronic sun exposure presented with bilateral brownish pigmentation over the face as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Melasma, especially in pregnant women, presents as bilateral, symmetrical brownish patches on the face, often linked to sun exposure and hormonal changes.

questions.text: Under the guidelines used in India, the dose of Vitamin A for 1-3 years old is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 2 Lac IU

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • According to the immunization schedule and the older Vitamin A prophylaxis program in India, the recommended dose for children up to 1 year of age is 1 lakh international units (IU). For infants below 6 months of age, a dose of 50,000 IU is administered.
  • • Once a child crosses the age of 1 year, the dose increases to 2 lakh IU. This dosage is applicable for toddlers, adolescents, and adults, and is used for both prophylaxis and treatment of Vitamin A deficiency.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. 50,000 IU: This dose is recommended for infants below 6 months of age.
  • • Option A. 50,000 IU: This dose is recommended for infants below 6 months of age.
  • • Option A. 50,000 IU:
  • • Option B. 1 Lac IU: This dose is given to children up to 1 year of age.
  • • Option B. 1 Lac IU: This dose is given to children up to 1 year of age.
  • • Option B. 1 Lac IU:
  • • Option D. 3 Lac IU: Not recommended under the guidelines of Vitamin A prophylaxis program.
  • • Option D. 3 Lac IU: Not recommended under the guidelines of Vitamin A prophylaxis program.
  • • Option D. 3 Lac IU:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For children aged 1-3 years, the recommended dose of Vitamin A under Indian guidelines is 2 lakh international units (IU).

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman is in labor. The cervix is 3 cm dilated and 70% effaced. A "bag of worms" is felt. What is the next best step? (INICET NOV 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Rupture membranes and confirm cord prolapse

options.label: C
options.text: Put the cord above the vertex

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Emergency LSCS

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of suspected cord prolapse during labor, an emergency LSCS is the recommended course of action to safely deliver the baby and minimize the risk of complications.

questions.text: In a seat belt injury, which of the following organs is most commonly affected? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hollow viscus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In seat belt injuries, hollow viscus organs, particularly the small intestine and colon, are most commonly affected due to their susceptibility to compression forces, emphasizing the importance of thorough evaluation for intra-abdominal injuries.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman, experiencing 6 years of infertility, possesses a BMI of 33 and exhibits facial hair. Further investigations have diagnosed her with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) and observed tubal spillage from both sides. Given her desire to conceive with her husband, what would be the most suitable management plan for her? (INICET MAY 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Weight loss+ Metformin + induction of ovulation with urinary gonadotrophins

options.label: B
options.text: Weight loss + folic acid, Try for spontaneous induction, if failed move to induction of ovulation

options.label: D
options.text: Weight loss+ Metformin + Induction of ovulation with clomiphene

questions.correct_answer: B. Weight loss + folic acid, Try for spontaneous induction, if failed move to induction of ovulation
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Weight loss + folic acid, try for spontaneous induction, if failed move to induction of ovulation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a woman with PCOS and infertility, the initial management should include weight loss and folic acid supplementation, with attempts at spontaneous ovulation before progressing to more invasive induction methods.

questions.text: Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium is mainly due to? ( INICET Nov 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Intracellular proteins

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ At Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium ,
  • ➤ At Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium
  • ➤ On each side of the membrane, each solution will be electrically neutral The product of diffusible ions on one side of the membrane will be equal to the product of diffusible ions on the other side of the membrane The electrochemical gradients produced by unequal distribution of charged ions produces a transmembrane potential difference which can be calculated using the Nernst equation The presence of impermeant ions on one side of the membrane creates an osmotic diffusion gradient attracting water into that compartment.
  • ➤ On each side of the membrane, each solution will be electrically neutral
  • ➤ The product of diffusible ions on one side of the membrane will be equal to the product of diffusible ions on the other side of the membrane
  • ➤ The electrochemical gradients produced by unequal distribution of charged ions produces a transmembrane potential difference which can be calculated using the Nernst equation
  • ➤ The presence of impermeant ions on one side of the membrane creates an osmotic diffusion gradient attracting water into that compartment.
  • ➤ Intracellular proteins are negatively charged non-permeable ions, then distribution of other permeable ions is affected in a predictable way (Donnan Effect) so that at equilibrium their concentration ratios are equal.

questions.text: Which of the following primary second messengers is involved in the contraction of ciliary muscles while focusing on near objects? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) IP3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ IP3 is the primary second messenger involved in the contraction of ciliary muscles necessary for focusing on near objects, mediated by M3 receptors.

questions.text: Decreased transferrin saturation is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Iron deficiency anemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective here is to understand the concept of transferrin saturation and how it relates to various conditions related to iron metabolism. Decreased transferrin saturation is typically seen in conditions of iron deficiency, such as iron deficiency anemia, where there is insufficient iron to fully saturate transferrin.

questions.text: A child presented with hydrocephalus, intracranial calcification, and bilateral chorioretinitis. What can be the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The classical triad of congenital toxoplasmosis includes hydrocephalus, intracranial calcifications, and chorioretinitis, which are key findings for diagnosis.

questions.text: Multiple abscesses with discharging sinuses, demonstrating sulphur granules in pus, are caused by: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Actinomyces

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Actinomycosis, particularly its cervicofacial form, is characterized by the formation of abscesses that discharge pus containing sulfur granules. This hallmark feature helps in diagnosing the disease, which requires prolonged antibiotic therapy due to its chronic and indurative nature.

questions.text: Which of the following effects of puberty are not mediated by estrogen? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hair growth

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hair growth during puberty is mediated by testosterone, not estrogen. Estrogen is responsible for breast development, internal genitalia development, menarche, growth spurt regulation, epiphyseal closure, and cervical mucus secretion.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 531, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 531, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6 th edition

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image, which developed after 3 days of catheterization. (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Fournier gangrene

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fournier gangrene is a urological emergency that involves necrotizing fasciitis of the external genitalia and requires prompt surgical debridement along with broad-spectrum antibiotics.

questions.text: At the 5th postnatal day, a woman presents with sadness, irritability, restlessness, and reduced sleep. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Postpartum blues

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Postpartum blues, also known as "baby blues," typically occur within the first few days after delivery and can last up to two weeks. It is characterized by mood swings, sadness, irritability, restlessness, and difficulty sleeping. These symptoms are usually mild and self-limiting, resolving on their own with support and reassurance.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Postpartum depression : This condition occurs after the first two weeks post-delivery and can persist for months. It includes more severe symptoms such as persistent sadness, lack of interest in the baby, feelings of hopelessness, and possibly suicidal thoughts.
  • • Option B. Postpartum depression
  • • more severe symptoms
  • • Option C. Postpartum anxiety : This condition involves excessive worry, anxiety, and often includes physical symptoms like palpitations or hyperventilation . It can occur at any time during the postpartum period.
  • • Option C. Postpartum anxiety
  • • palpitations or hyperventilation
  • • Option D. Postpartum psychosis : This is a rare but severe condition that usually occurs within the first few weeks after delivery. It involves symptoms such as hallucinations, delusions, severe agitation, and risk of harm to the mother or baby.
  • • Option D. Postpartum psychosis
  • • severe condition

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Postpartum blues are common in the first few days after delivery and are characterized by sadness, irritability, restlessness, and reduced sleep. The condition is generally mild and self-limiting, resolving with support and care.

questions.text: Numerous youngsters from a specific community arrived at a medical facility and were diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). It was assumed that it is due to the presence of cytotoxic waste in the water of that community. If a case-control investigation were to be conducted to find the potential association between the chemical waste and ALL, what would serve as the control group? (NEET PG 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Children from the area exposed, but unaffected with the disease

options.label: B
options.text: Children from the area not exposed and affected with the disease

options.label: C
options.text: Children coming to the OPD who do not have the disease

options.label: D
options.text: All children with ALL irrespective of exposure status

questions.correct_answer: C. Children coming to the OPD who do not have the disease
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Children coming to the OPD who do not have the disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a case-control study investigating the association between chemical waste exposure and acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), the control group should consist of children coming to the OPD who do not have the disease (ALL). This ensures a proper baseline for comparison to identify potential risk factors associated with the disease.

questions.text: A young man presents with skin lesions as shown in the image below. All of the following organisms can spread through dermal and subcutaneous lymphatics, except? ( INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ While Sporothrix schenckii, Nocardia asteroides, and Mycobacterium marinum are known to spread through dermal and subcutaneous lymphatics, causing lymphocutaneous lesions, Staphylococcus aureus typically causes localized skin infections and does not exhibit this pattern of spread.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct treatment protocol for pulmonary tuberculosis in children? (Fmge July 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2HRZE + 4 HRE

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct treatment protocol for pulmonary tuberculosis in children involves 2 months of HRZE followed by 4 months of HRE, aligning with WHO guidelines for pediatric TB treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following forms the lateral boundary of the femoral triangle? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Medial margin of sartorius

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The femoral triangle is a triangular muscular depression located in the upper part of the thigh. Its boundaries are formed by the inguinal ligament (base), the medial margin of the sartorius muscle (lateral boundary), and the medial border of the adductor longus muscle (medial boundary). The apex of the triangle is formed by the intersection of the sartorius and adductor longus muscles.
  • • The sartorius muscle, the longest muscle in the body, originates from the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) and forms the lateral boundary of the femoral triangle with its medial margin. The adductor longus muscle, originating from the pubic tubercle area, forms the medial boundary of the triangle.
  • • The floor of the femoral triangle is formed by the adductor longus, pectineus, psoas major tendon, and iliacus muscle (Mnemonic "APPI"). The roof of the triangle is formed by the skin, superficial fascia, and deep fascia.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Lateral margin of adductor longus: Incorrect. The adductor longus muscle forms the medial boundary of the femoral triangle, not the lateral boundary.
  • • Option A. Lateral margin of adductor longus:
  • • Option B. Medial margin of adductor longus: Incorrect. The medial margin of the adductor longus muscle forms the medial boundary of the femoral triangle, not the lateral boundary.
  • • Option B. Medial margin of adductor longus:
  • • Option C. Lateral margin of sartorius: Incorrect. The sartorius muscle forms the lateral boundary of the femoral triangle, but it is the medial margin of the sartorius that specifically forms this boundary.
  • • Option C. Lateral margin of sartorius:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The medial margin of the sartorius muscle forms the lateral boundary of the femoral triangle, while the medial border of the adductor longus muscle forms the medial boundary.

questions.text: Which of the following is a primary skin lesion? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Purpura

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Purpura is a primary skin lesion indicative of an underlying vascular or coagulation disorder , differentiating it from secondary skin lesions such as crusts, atrophy, and induration , which result from external factors or the progression of skin diseases is also crucial.
  • ➤ Purpura
  • ➤ vascular or coagulation disorder
  • ➤ secondary
  • ➤ crusts, atrophy, and induration
  • ➤ external factors
  • ➤ progression

References:

  • ↳ Reference:
  • ↳ Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9 th Edition Chapter 4 page no 4.10
  • ↳ Question Level – Intermediate
  • ↳ Question Level – Intermediate

  • ↳ Question Id-7437 Unique Key-Q1311505

questions.text: A child presents with left to right shunt and high output cardiac failure. The following is his MRI. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Vein of Galen malformation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vein of Galen malformation is a critical diagnosis to consider in infants presenting with signs of high-output cardiac failure, and it can be identified with specific imaging findings such as large flow voids on MRI indicative of abnormal vascular connections.

questions.text: Vitamin A deficiency is characteristic of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Bitot spots

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bitot spots are a characteristic sign of vitamin A deficiency, appearing as dry, foamy patches on the conjunctiva and representing stage X1B of xerophthalmia.

questions.text: A woman presents with numbness of her fingertips. On examination, her face is tightened. The antinuclear antibody (ANA) is found to be positive and immunofluorescence shows the nucleolar pattern. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Systemic sclerosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Systemic sclerosis (scleroderma) is associated with positive ANA with a nucleolar pattern, skin tightening, and symptoms like Raynaud's phenomenon. This combination of clinical findings and specific antibody patterns helps in diagnosing systemic sclerosis.

questions.text: Which of the following tests can be used if otoacoustic emissions is absent for screening? (INICET NOV 2022) Pure tone audiometry Tympanometry Free field audiometry Speech audiometry
questions.explanation: Ans. A) 2 and 4

questions.text: Following delivery at a PHC, a patient was referred with the following image. On examination, there is a tear extending to the rectum. Identify the type of tear. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A 4th degree tear involves disruption of the anal sphincters and rectal mucosa, making it the most severe form of perineal tear during childbirth.

questions.text: A petechial rash is associated with all the following, except? ( INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Roseola infantum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Roseola infantum is characterized by a rapid onset of a high fever followed by a rash, but it does not typically present with petechial rashes. In contrast, Zika virus, Kyasanur Forest disease, and West Nile fever can cause petechial rashes as part of their clinical manifestations.
  • ➤ Roseola infantum is characterized by a rapid onset of a high fever followed by a rash, but it does not typically present with petechial rashes. In contrast, Zika virus, Kyasanur Forest disease, and West Nile fever can cause petechial rashes as part of their clinical manifestations.

questions.text: In the given image, the tendon marked by the arrow is: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Flexor carpi radialis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image shows the anterior compartment of the forearm, focusing on the tendons near the wrist. The arrow is pointing to a tendon that runs from the forearm to the wrist and to the palm. This tendon belongs to the flexor carpi radialis muscle. The flexor carpi radialis is one of the superficial flexor muscles of the forearm. It plays a crucial role in flexion and abduction of the wrist.
  • • Flexor Carpi Radialis: The flexor carpi radialis tendon is located just lateral to the palmaris longus tendon. It is prominent and easily palpable in many individuals.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Flexor carpi ulnaris : This is incorrect. The flexor carpi ulnaris tendon is located medial to the palmaris longus tendon and runs towards the pisiform bone.
  • • Option B. Flexor carpi ulnaris
  • • Option C. Flexor digitorum superficialis : This is incorrect. The flexor digitorum superficialis tendons are deeper and run to the fingers, responsible for flexion of the middle phalanges.
  • • Option C. Flexor digitorum superficialis
  • • Option D. Palmaris longus: This is incorrect. The palmaris longus tendon runs from the forearm to the palm and is more centrally located in the wrist. It is a thin tendon that is absent in about 14% of the population.
  • • Option D. Palmaris longus:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The flexor carpi radialis is a superficial flexor muscle of the forearm with a prominent tendon that runs from the forearm to the base of the second and third metacarpals, playing a key role in wrist flexion and abduction.

questions.text: A patient being treated for hypertriglyceridemia developed flushing, gout, hyperglycemia, and raised liver enzymes. Which drug is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Nicotinamide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nicotinamide (niacin) is associated with flushing, gout, hyperglycemia, and raised liver enzymes, making it the likely cause of these symptoms in a patient being treated for hypertriglyceridemia

questions.text: Which of the following eye sign is given in the image? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tache noire

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tache noire is a postmortem change characterized by a triangular brownish discoloration on the sclera due to drying and deposition of bacteria and dust, typically occurring within a few hours after death.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male came with a history of progressive dysphagia, initially to solid foods and now to liquids too. He has also experienced significant weight loss over the past few months. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for diagnosing the underlying cause of his symptoms? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Upper GI Endoscopy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Upper GI endoscopy is the first-line diagnostic tool for evaluating a patient with progressive dysphagia and significant weight loss, as it allows for direct visualization and biopsy to establish a definitive diagnosis.

questions.text: The cross product ratio can be obtained by: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Case control study

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The cross-product ratio, or odds ratio, is a measure of association commonly derived from case-control studies to determine the relationship between exposure and outcome.

questions.text: Salter Harris Type 1 injury passes through which zone? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hypertrophic zone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hypertrophic zone of the physis has a high bone turnover. It is the area where all Salter-Harris injuries occur. Thus, the Type I injuries occurs in the hypertrophic zone of the physis.
  • ➤ Hypertrophic zone of the physis has a high bone turnover.
  • ➤ It is the area where all Salter-Harris injuries occur.
  • ➤ Thus, the Type I injuries occurs in the hypertrophic zone of the physis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Kawasaki disease? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Non-purulent conjunctivitis is a feature of Kawasaki disease, whereas purulent conjunctivitis is not.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman with BMI 32, was on atypical antipsychotic drugs. She presented with a complaint of weight gain. Which of the following drugs is least commonly associated with weight gain? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ziprasidone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Among antipsychotic medications, ziprasidone is least commonly associated with weight gain, making it a better option for patients concerned about this side effect.

questions.text: A farmer presents with pain and discharge in his left eye. He says that he sustained an injury caused by a leaf a few days back. What is the finding seen in the image? ( INICET Nov 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hypopyon

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hypopyon is points to severe intraocular inflammation needing prompt treatment to preserve eye function and prevent potential complications. The presence of hypopyon after an injury with organic material highly suggests a fungal etiology, requiring specific antifungal treatment alongside broad-spectrum antibacterial coverage.
  • ➤ Hypopyon

questions.text: A 35-year-old HIV positive patient presents with mucosal lesions in the mouth as shown in the image below. On microscopy, budding yeasts and pseudohyphae are seen. What is the likely diagnosis? ( NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Oral candidiasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Oral candidiasis is a common opportunistic infection in HIV-positive individuals, characterized by white, patchy lesions in the oral cavity and the presence of Candida species on microscopic examination. Recognizing this condition and distinguishing it from other oral lesions based on clinical presentation and risk factors is crucial for appropriate management, which may include antifungal therapies like nystatin, ketoconazole, or fluconazole.

questions.text: Ketosis is common in type 1 DM due to: ( INICET Nov 2020) 1. Decreased beta-oxidation of fatty acids 2. Increased mobilization of fat from the adipose cell 3. Decreased acetyl Co in TCA cycle 4. Increased beta-hydroxy butyrate synthase
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 2, 3 and 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Ketosis in type 1 diabetes mellitus is caused by increased mobilization of fat from adipose tissue, decreased entry of acetyl CoA into the TCA cycle, and increased production of ketone bodies, particularly beta-hydroxybutyrate.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient presents to the hospital with complaints of abdominal pain and discomfort for the past few months. The patient also reported experiencing weight loss and loss of appetite. On evaluation, a mass is palpable in the upper abdomen, and an endoscopy shows an ulcerated lesion in the stomach. A biopsy of the lesion is taken and sent for immunohistochemistry. The biopsy sample is found to be positive for CD117 and negative for LCA, cytokeratin, and S100. Based on these findings. What is the most likely diagnosis? ( INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) GIST

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ GISTs are mesenchymal tumors that typically occur in the gastrointestinal tract. They often express CD117 (c-kit), a marker commonly associated with GIST. The negative staining for LCA (Leukocyte Common Antigen), cytokeratin, and S100 helps rule out other possibilities and supports the diagnosis of GIST.

questions.text: A 2-year-old toddler with a weight of 11 kg was brought to the pediatric outpatient department. The child exhibited a respiratory rate of 38 breaths per minute and upon examination, noticeable chest indrawing was detected. What is the next step of management? (NEET PG 2020)

options.label: B
options.text: Urgent referral to the tertiary care centre immediately

options.label: C
options.text: Administer IV antibiotics and ask the patient to be brought after 24 hours

questions.correct_answer: A. Oral amoxicillin for five days
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Oral amoxicillin for five days

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented in OPD with complaints of fever, night sweats, and weight loss for 2 months. On examination, lymphadenopathy was present. They were non-tender, rubbery in consistency, located in the supraclavicular and inguinal regions on both sides. Peripheral smear showed the presence of bi-nucleated cells. Which markers can be identified in this condition? (INICET NOV 2022) CD15 CD30 CD19 CD3
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1 and 2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Hodgkin's lymphoma, Reed-Sternberg cells characteristically express CD15 and CD30, making these markers essential for diagnosis.

questions.text: A 59-year-old patient who underwent cataract surgery, presented with gradual diminution of vision in the operated eye, suggesting secondary cataract. Which laser is used for the management of this patient? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Nd:YAG

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Various lasers and their uses in ophthalmological procedures: -
  • ➤ Various lasers and their uses in ophthalmological procedures: -

questions.text: In a solid organ transplantation, which organ is associated with a higher incidence of rejection? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lungs

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lung transplantation is associated with a higher incidence of rejection compared to other solid organ transplants due to the lungs' constant exposure to environmental antigens, emphasizing the need for vigilant monitoring and immunosuppressive therapy in lung transplant recipients.
